definition.title: What is a Signature Story?
definition.content: A signature story is your go-to illustration that demonstrates your expertise and methodology in action. It's the story you tell in every keynote, podcast, and sales conversation because it perfectly captures what you do and why it works.

tips: Start in the middle of the action - skip the setup and drop the listener into the tension
Include specific details - names, numbers, and sensory details make stories believable
Show the moment of change - what was the insight or decision that changed everything?
End with a universal lesson - make sure the takeaway applies to your listener's situation too

examples.title: Client Transformation Story
examples.content: When I met Sarah, she was working 80-hour weeks and her business was plateaued at $400K. Six months later, she was working 40 hours and had crossed $1M. The difference? We eliminated 80% of what she thought was essential.

examples.title: Personal Origin Story
examples.content: I was sitting in a hospital bed, realizing I'd sacrificed my health for success. That moment changed everything. Now I help executives build wealth without burning out.

examples.title: Methodology Discovery Story
examples.content: After my third failed product launch, I finally saw the pattern. I'd been building what I wanted, not what they needed. That insight became the core of my Customer-First Framework.

faq.question: What makes a good signature story?
faq.answer: A good signature story has relatable characters, specific details, emotional stakes, and a clear demonstration of your unique approach.

faq.question: Should I use a client story or my own?
faq.answer: Both work. Client stories demonstrate results, while personal stories show your journey. Have one of each ready.

faq.question: How do I tell it naturally?
faq.answer: Practice until you know the beats, not the exact words. The story should feel like you're sharing with a friend, not reciting.

faq.question: When should I use my signature story?
faq.answer: In keynotes, podcast interviews, sales conversations, and whenever you need to illustrate your methodology or expertise.
